Award.AwardTitle: Positive definiteness preserving approaches for viscoelastic flow of Oldroyd-B and FENE-CR types: Applications to particulate flow
Award.AbstractNarration:
The motion of particles in fluids is not only of fundamental theoretical interest, but is also of importance in many applications to industrial processes involving particle-laden materials. While numerical methods for simulating particle motion in Newtonian fluids have been very successful, numerically simulating particle motion in viscoelastic fluids is quite complicated and challenging. Through the computational methodologies explored in this project, efficient simulations will be performed to investigate and understand the complex fluid-particle and particle-particle dynamics in viscoelastic fluids, especially the sedimentation, migration, lift-off and resuspension of particles in three dimensional channels. The simulation tools developed in this project will have significant engineering and biomedical applications, such as proppant transport in hydraulic fracturing operations used in oil and gas wells and the elasto-inertial particle focusing for developing cost-effective labs-on-a-chip such as cell counting devices.

Numerical methods for simulating particle motion in viscoelastic fluids is quite complicated and challenging. One of the difficulties for simulating viscoelastic flows is the breakdown of the numerical methods. It has been widely believed that the lack of positive definiteness preserving property of the conformation tensor at the discrete level during the entire time integration is one of the reasons for the breakdown. To preserve the positive definiteness property of the conformation tensor, the constitutive equation can be reformulated as equations for the matrix logarithm of the conformation tensor to preserve the property of the positive definiteness as Fattal and Kupferman did. Another approach is to factorize the conformation tensor and then to write down the new associated equations at the discrete level, and hence the positive definiteness of the conformation tensor is forced as Lozinski and Owens did. In this project, we aim to extend and combine fictitious domain based distributed Lagrange multiplier methods, which is for simulating particle motion in fluid, with either the Lozinski and Owens' factorization approach or the log-conformation tensor approach via an operator splitting technique to preserve the positive definiteness property of the conformation tensor for simulating particle motion in viscoelastic fluids of Oldroyd-B and FENE-P types. Through the computational methodologies proposed in this project, efficient simulations will be performed to investigate and understand the complex fluid-particle and particle-particle dynamics in viscoelastic fluids, especially the sedimentation, migration, lift-off and resuspension of particles in two and three dimensional channels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of the particle motion in viscoelastic fluids is not only of  fundamental theoretical interest, but also of importance in many  applications to industrial processes involving particle-laden materials,  such as  suspensions of solid particles in polymeric solutions which are pumped into hydraulically-induced fractures in oil and gas wells.

The main outcome is that robust numerical methodologies have been developed  for simulating the motion of particles in viscoelastic fluids. Via an operator splitting method,  we have developed computational methodologies through the combination of a distributed Lagrange multiplier/fictitious domain method, the Lozinski and Owens’ factorization approach and finite element approximations.

The first main result is that we have extended our previously developed  computational methods for simulating the particle motion in Oldroyd-B fluids   to those for simulating the particle motion in viscoelastic fluids of FENE-CR  type, which is a more realistic model. Via direct numerical simulations, we  obtained that it is easier to obtain chains of many particles in Oldroyd-B  fluid since its coil maximum extension is unlimited. The shorter polymer  extension of those FENE-CR type fluids can not hold many particles together.   Also our simulations show that, as expected, the values of the elasticity and Mach numbers are the major determining factors concerning the particle chain  formation in Oldroyd-B fluids. The numerical methods and  simulating results  have been published in two peer-review articles, one in "Journal of  Non-Newtonian Fluid Mechanics" and the other in "Physical  Review E".

The second one is that, for particle interaction in a bounded shear flow of very  viscous incompressible fluids, we have developed new computational methodologies and a collision strategy for treating two particles interacting next to each  other in both Newtonian and viscoelastic fluids. We obtained that, unlike the two balls interacting in a bounded shear flow of a Newtonian fluid, the two  balls interact in a viscoelastic fluid differently. They can easily form a  two-ball chain and then such chain tumbles due to the fluid elasticity force.   These methods and numerical results have been published in two peer-review  articles, one in "Journal of Computational Physics" and the other in "Computers  & Fluids".
 
The third one is that robust numerical methods have been developed for  simulating balls settling in a vertical channel filled with an Oldroyd-B fluid at higher elasticity number. There are conflicting experimental results  concerning particle settling in viscoelastic fluids of Boger type.  Via numerical simulations, we have studied two balls interacting with a side-by-side initial  configuration. Up to the strength of the fluid elasticity force and the particle  density, the two balls can either stay apart and interact periodically or form  a two-ball vertical chain. The results have been accepted for publication in a  peer-review journal, "Physics of Fluids".
